author: Marvin Bertin
title: Self Governing Stake Pools

assessments.note: Decentralization is one of the key elements of the Cardano roadmap. I believe that allowing a self governance within the stake pool would accelerate the process.
This suggestion would provide a good answer to the growing number of pools, that are controlled by "big players". It brings the idea of decentralisation one step further.

An interesting concept for sure. I like the idea of these more automated stake pool operators where the decisions are not completely up to them, I think at that point they basically become providers of computing/networking resources. It could simplify the process and provide a lot of benefits to the ecosystem

I find the need to change how a stake pool operates a bit ambitious. I'm sure the governance system that was drawn out by the creators of these stake pools understood why these stake pool operators have people's stake in their care. They'd want to maintain their reputation of operating fairly and diligently. This ensures the trustless system continues. Besides, it's too much time to spend on the activities of a stake pool. It should be as mindless and less time consuming as possible.

I'd advice you look at the idea again and think of how to refine it for the better.

It is a great idea, It creates governance within governance but I can see the opposite effect that could lead to the detriment of the pool itself. If there is malice it can also become a tool that can hurt the network. Not saying that it would happen but when we talk about humans banding together for whatever reason the possibilities exist. This can also impact on identity issues and the failure of one to affect others. I can see the immense benefits but also the detriments in this idea.

Interesting proposal, but not aligned with the challenge set for fund 6.
This is not a critical priority as it does not solve a problem. Instead it proposes an improvement on the current system.
Consider filing this proposal in 'Developer ecosystem' to improve the chances of adoption.
The concept is realistic for a portion of stake pools, not all. It should be up to them to implement a DAO if it is their wish to do so.
Good idea, but probably to specific to set as a whole challenge for Fund 6

This is addressing an important topic. Right now we need to get Cardano as a whole from 'benevolent dictatorship by IOG' (I mean this very friendly and positive) to full decentralization and community control. There are still a lot of challenges on that road. I support this idea, but I would go for this much later. There are also clear advantages of running stake-pools as small private enterprises. This simplifies the otherwise complex topic of how to deal with the pledge and with liabilities in case of any kind of 'incidents'. I suggest to invest the USD 200.000 otherwise right now.

I think this is a very good proposal for improving upon the intended decentralization of the network. I gave it 4 stars because at the current point in our timeline I would not fully say it is "critical", there are some things that are certainly higher priority, but as far as long term goals go this is an excellent proposition to further Cardano's mission and has a number of potential side benefits for SPOs and delegates alike.

If demonstratively effective, secure dapp contracts and DEX projects were completed at this time, I would have given this 5 stars.
The block diagram is really self explaining. It would most likely require the usage of a native token other than ADA, but this is definitely feasible.
The various aspects of the solution are well described and the suggested solutions sound very feasable.

Cardano's governance system would have to play a more integral role in this for the project to success I believe, but I don't see why that would be an issue, just may need to overcome some challenges.  There isn't much to say about the 'team' here. Is there one? more information would be needed on how this will be accomplished and by who.

I don't think it's possible to implement this project with the current state of adoption. If there is a problem with the way stake pools operate, it would be apparent to everyone at this point. I don't think we should fix what is not broken.
The community has the resources to make this happen and develop a platform conducive of these points highlighted.

The attached image and challenge brief provide a decent plan to execute this proposal. I also envision a base of support within the community for something like this.

More elaboration about the requested funding amount would be welcome. Why does it cost 200000 USD and what is it going to be used on exactly?

I think that our possible Governance Symposium or similar activities (see Greg Plendleburry's Proposal during Fund 3 for Fund 5) should primarily focus on getting the basics settled. First of all, we as community need to mature to take over the actual control from IOG. Hand in hand with this, important legal necessities together with the foundation need to be clarified. Stake-pools run as DAO is a very interesting additional option, but for me a clear next step further out in the future. We need to learn crawling before running.

I think in time systems like the proposal discusses could be well within the capability of the community to implement. We have native assets to issue governance tokens, and with the launch of smart contracts I think this could present an excellent challenge for developers that would serve a high quality long-term purpose.
The structure of the block diagram indicates also on how the funds distribution is handled, and how the governance would be successfully adapted within a pool

The proposal states components that needs to be addresses and aspects that needs to be addresses within these components. It is not described, how the progress shold be measured but as the needs to be a kind of product at the end, it should be easy to establish milestones towards this goal.

I think that if a stake pool operator does not have control over the the rewards they have anymore and they are decided by community then it should be possible to call this a success. I don't think this would be accomplished at once, however, so I think defining more milestones would be appropriate in this process. I imagine it being a gradual process similar to the approach IOG took to decentralize the system by allowing SPO to mint blocks

If this project is implemented, it would be easy for us to see how far it has gone by looking at the stake pools that implement this form of governance. However, I do not see the need for use to fix what is not broken.

Please find a way to revise this proposal. I see potential in this project but it's not giving anything concrete yet.

The project scope and solutions are sound to this challenge. There are advantages and disadvantages of opening up this process. Perhaps the disadvantages could be explored to assure that it does not out weight the disadvantages.

Clear set and explained criteria.

There is a plan that almost looks like a roadmap and could be transitioned into one with little effort.

There is no consideration of risk factors in this proposal. What could go wrong?
Great idea. I think the problem you are trying to solve is very relevant.
This is another rather complex topic when leaving the surface and going deeper. I am sure that it can be successfully done, but I propose to wait with this.

I think that this proposal will introduce some unanticipated challenges if pursued, but broadly I feel that the author has presented the correct metrics responses to such a challenge will need to track. Risk assessment of this model could have been explored a little more deeply but that is perhaps a burden for the subsequent solutions to bear.

importance: A stake pool's management is centralized which hinders delegator engagement, requires trust and lacks accountability towards the community
success: Pools becoming decentralized autonomous org. where the power is in the hands of the delegators and decisions are made by vote consensus
